summary.text_en: While working for Marconi's (`marconi_radio_1895`) company, John Ambrose Fleming invented the 'Fleming Valve'. This was the *first* practical 'vacuum tube' and the first 'diode'. Fleming put the 'Edison Effect' (`edison_effect_1883`)â€”which Edison had discovered and ignored 20 years priorâ€”to practical use. He realized this 'one-way valve' for current was the *perfect* tool to 'detect' faint, high-frequency radio waves by 'rectifying' their AC signal into a usable DC signal for a headset. This was the birth of 'electronics'.
key_points_en: Used as a 'Rectifier' / 'Detector' for radio waves
Turns an AC signal into a DC signal

story.text_en:
Marconi's (`marconi_radio_1895`) radio system had a *huge* weak point: its 'receiver', a device called a 'coherer', was unreliable and insensitive. Fleming (as a consultant for Marconi) was tasked with finding a better 'detector'. He remembered the 'odd' effect Edison (`edison_effect_1883`) had discovered 20 years earlier: current *only* flows *one way* in a vacuum, from the hot filament to the plate.
Fleming realized: a radio wave (`hertz_waves_1887`) is an 'Alternating Current' (AC)â€”it 'wiggles' back and forth. But a *headphone* (`bell_telephone_1876`) can *only* hear 'Direct Current' (DC). He needed a *one-way valve*!
The 'Fleming Valve' *was* that valve. It let *only one half* of the radio wave's wiggle (the positive part) pass through, while *blocking* the other half (the negative part). This 'rectified' the AC signal into a 'pulsing DC' signal that a headphone or galvanometer could actually detect.

fun_facts.text_en: Fleming was very 'short-sighted' about his invention. He *only* saw it as a 'radio telegraphy detector' and failed to see its much greater potential (as an 'electronic' switch).
Lee de Forest (`de_forest_audion_1907`) improved Fleming's 'diode' (2-elements) into a 'triode' (3-elements) just two years later, sparking a 20-year-long patent war.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine a radio signal (`hertz_waves_1887`) is a 'swing' going *back and forth* (AC).
But your 'headphones' can *only* understand 'pushes in one direction' (DC).
Fleming used the 'Edison Effect' (`edison_effect_1883`) to build a 'one-way turnstile'.
This 'turnstile' (the diode) *only* let the 'forward' part of the swing pass through, while *blocking* all the 'backward' swings. This turned the 'back-and-forth' motion into a 'push... push... push...' (pulsing DC).
*This* was a signal the headphones could 'hear'. Fleming had invented the 'cornerstone' of electronics.

applications.text_en: The diode's first use was as a vastly superior 'detector' for radio, replacing Marconi's (`marconi_radio_1895`) unreliable 'coherer'.

applications.text_en: The diode is the ancestor of *all* 'rectifiers' (devices that turn AC into DC). Your phone 'charger' is, in essence, a modern (solid-state) rectifier.

impact.text_en: The 'Fleming Valve' was the *true start* of the 'Electronic Revolution'. Edison (`edison_effect_1883`) found the *physics*, but Fleming was the first to *engineer* it into an *'electronic component'*. This simple 'vacuum tube diode' was the first device with *no moving parts*, and it led *directly* to Lee de Forest's (`de_forest_audion_1907`) 'triode' (the amplifier), which enabled *all* radio broadcasting, television, and early computers (`eniac_1946`).

influenced_by.contribution_en: The Edison Effect (the 'scientific curiosity' that Fleming turned into a 'useful device')
Marconi (his radio's 'need for a better detector' was Fleming's motivation)

influenced.contribution_en: Lee de Forest (his 'Triode' was a *direct modification* of Fleming's 'Diode', by adding a 3rd element)
The 20th Century Electronics Revolution (all vacuum tube technology starts here)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Fleming 'weaponized' the Edison Effect, invented the first vacuum tube, and started the Electronic Age.

quiz.question_en: What key function did John Fleming's 'Diode' (Fleming Valve) use the 'Edison Effect' to perform?
options_en: Rectify an AC signal into a DC signal
quiz.explanation_en: The 'Edison Effect' (`edison_effect_1883`) proved current only flows *one way* in a vacuum. Fleming used this 'one-way valve' to 'filter out' the negative half of an AC radio wave, turning it into a pulsing DC signal that could be 'detected' by a headset.
